awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stability of Nonlinear Wave Structures in Lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigators of this collaborative research project study the stability of nonlinear waves in lattices.  The interplay of spatially discrete structure and nonlinearity in many physical and biological systems, from mechanical metamaterials and nanoelectromechanical devices to biopolymers, often results in formation of nonlinear waveforms that either coherently transport or release energy as they propagate through the system.  In particular, recent experimental and theoretical work on granular materials has advanced the understanding of the conditions for existence and properties of a variety of such structures, including traveling pulses and shock waves.  However, much less is known about the conditions under which these structures are stable.  The goal of this project is to obtain such criteria in a framework that extends earlier work to more general classes of waves and to broader settings that account for the effects of higher dimensions, lattice structure, external driving, and damping.  Fundamental understanding of stability criteria for nonlinear waves is important in a number of different fields, including materials science, condensed matter physics, mechanical engineering, and biophysics.  The insights provided by this work can be helpful in designing new devices for energy channeling, shock absorption, and vibration mitigation.  An integral component of this collaborative project is teaching and training graduate students in the interdisciplinary research area of nonlinear wave phenomena in lattices.  To this end, graduate students participate in the research.

This project builds on the ongoing joint work of the principal investigators on stability of solitary traveling waves in one-dimensional lattices and its intimate connection to the stability of discrete breathers.  This involves developing novel analytical stability criteria, as well as state-of-the-art numerical approaches necessary to extend this framework to broader settings, including two-dimensional and heterogeneous lattices, while considering more general classes of traveling waves.  In particular, stability of waveforms with oscillatory tails, such as nanoptera in resonant granular chains and generalized kinks in dislocation models, is investigated.  The project involves studying dynamic implications of instability and examining the effects of dissipation, long-range interactions, and external driving.  The project's goals also include clarifying the relation of the linear spectra associated with a solitary traveling wave (and their variations at instability critical points) to the corresponding discrete breather Floquet spectra, as well as connecting the stability criteria for such waves to the established functional analytic framework for continuum systems.  Graduate students participate in the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The combination of spatial discreteness and nonlinearity, widely relevant to many physical and biological systems, often results in the emergence of nonlinear coherent wave structures such as  traveling waves and discrete breathers. These bear a central role in energy transport and localization phenomena. This collaborative research project has provided insights into the effects of the form and the range of the interactions, viscous damping, external driving and resonances on the existence, stability and properties of such waves. It has demonstrated that dispersive continuum approximations must be sufficiently complex in order to describe kinetics of transition fronts, strong localization of solitary waves and other important phenomena observed in discrete settings. The project's contributions include systematic stability investigations of traveling waves and discrete breathers in different settings that demonstrated the connection between the onset of instability and change in monotonicity of the relevant diagnostic curve (of energy vs. speed, for traveling waves and energy vs. frequency for discrete breathers). The results also clarified the dynamic consequences of the instability. The project has provided further insight into existence and stability of moving discrete breathers and the associated nonlinear resonances in the energy-frequency curve. It has also contributed to the understanding of nonlinear phenomena in novel mechanical metamaterials by exploring existence, stability and bifurcation structure of discrete breathers and providing a unified description of different types of transition waves.  

In addition to the concrete findings in the realm of nonlinear dynamical lattices, the project enabled a wide range of additional contributions in nonlinear wave systems relevant to atomic physics, nonlinear optics, electrical lattices, magnetic systems and beyond. It also provided a platform for collaboration across disciplinary boundaries of applied mathematicians with theoretical, as well as experimental physicists and engineers and the opportunity for young researchers to be trained within and to benefit from such inter-disciplinary collaborations.

By advancing the fundamental understanding of existence, properties and stability of nonlinear waves in discrete structures, the project impacted a number of different fields, including applied mathematics, materials science, condensed matter physics, mechanical engineering and biophysics. Moreover, methods developed in the course of this work may be used to study other discrete nonlinear systems more broadly than the concrete applications herein.

The results of this research were made available to an interdisciplinary audience through a wide range of journal publications and conference as well as seminar presentations. A workshop co-organized by one of the co-PIs has facilitated an exchange of ideas between different communities working on nonlinear wave phenomena. At the same time, a seminar series organized for the past 2 1/2 years from the other co-PI has widely benefited the community of nonlinear waves allowing it to come together and have a sense of community and connection even throughout the very difficult times of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The research training of a Ph.D. student in this interdisciplinary field at the University of Pittsburgh actively involved both PIs, while numerous additional young researchers (undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral) were involved in the project at UMass, despite the absence of a budget for their support. This concerted effort towards training and the inclusion of material related to the topics of the proposal in courses on Dynamical Systems and Partial Differential Equations has offered the opportunity to students and junior colleagues to be introduced to this fascinating subject.
